Instrument.name: Near Infrared Camera for CLEM1
Instrument.description:
The Near Infrared Camera (NIR), part of the Clementine mission, utilizes a cryogenically cooled 256x256 indium antimonide focal plane array (FPA) for lunar observations. Operating at around 70 K, it demonstrated stability during over 500 hours of space operation. The camera collects data over a wavelength range of 1.0 to 5.5 microns and is programmed for various integration times, gains, and offsets. Its primary goal is lunar mineral mapping using observations with low solar phase angles, achieving resolutions from 100 meters/pixel at periselene to 400 meters/pixel at the poles.
Calibration procedures include radiometric calibration to ensure accurate signal conversion and geometric calibration to correct optical distortions, which are minimal. The camera features three operational modes, including selectable integration times and adjustable gain and offset settings for optimal observations across different lunar latitudes. Notable specifications include an A/D resolution of 8 bits, a frame rate of up to 7.1 Hz, and various filters covering specific spectral bands. The NIR camera was designed to ensure sufficient overlap in image coverage for cartographic applications while maintaining a proper signal-to-noise ratio.
